items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this morning and into the afternoon. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 6th December 2021.

High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on the evening of Sunday 05/12/2021, between 6pm and 8pm. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday evening, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Basford Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday, 05/12/2021. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle. Further showers are possible in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 05/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Riccal and its tributaries including Bonfield Gill, Bogmire Gill, Ellerker Beck, Keld Spring Beck and Walmouth Beck. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated on Sunday afternoon 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hints river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning, 05/12/21.
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today and into tomorrow, 06/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Doveridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday, 05/12/21. Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Rocester and Clay Mills. Further rainfall is forecast today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels remain high as a result of rainfall and snowmelt over the past few days, and a slight further rise is possible today, Sunday 05/12/2021, following overnight rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday, 05/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast and river levels could remain high for a number of days. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Sunday afternoon 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.76 mAOD at 15:00 on 05/12/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 22 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:15am to 13:15pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.83mAODN at 12:15pm, on Sunday 5th December 2021, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely, between 11:00am to 13:00pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.63mAODN at 12:00pm, on Sunday 5th December 2021, which is 0.38m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021.

This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00am to 13:00pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021.  Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.63mAODN at 12:00pm, on Sunday 5th December 2021, which is 0.38m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).    Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021.

items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45am to 14:45pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it, is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.52mAODN at 12:45pm, on Sunday 5th December 2021, which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 3pm today, Sunday 5th December 2021.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
The high tides at 11:30 AM and midnight on Sunday 05/12/2021 are not expected to reach flood alert levels. However, forecasts indicate that further alerts/warnings maybe issued from Monday to Wednesday as subsequent high tides coincide with strong winds leading to increased surge.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The high tide related to this flood alert has now passed.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences at Seaburn Lower Promenade and Seaham Harbour and Docks as a result of this afternoon’s high tide and strong winds. Wave overtopping is expected between 14:30 and 18:00 today, 05/12/2021. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 today, 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Due to the unsettled weather affecting the area, tide levels will remain a little elevated over the next few days. The current forecast suggests that further minor impact flooding may occur at high tide (expected at 13:00) on Tuesday 07/12/2021. However, there is a low chance that a developing deep low pressure could change its course and track over southern England which will lead to unusually high surge tides on Tuesday and Wednesday (08/12/2021). If required, we will issue advice on Monday 06/12/2021.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this morning and into the afternoon. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 6th December 2021.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However tide levels on Saturday, Sunday and early next week are forecast to be lower than those experienced Saturday morning (by 20 to 40 cm). Saturday evening's tide at 23:15 on 04/12/2021 will be lower by 0.01 m and is forecast to be 6.02 metres Chart Datum (2.97 mAOD) at Littlehampton. No more than a very small amount of spray is expected to affect Climping seafront. There is the possibility of another low pressure weather system next Tuesday (07/12/2021) and Wednesday (08/12/2021). It is most likely that flood impacts will be no worse than those experienced in recent days. However, there is a very low likelihood of extremely strong winds and large waves, which could affect the beach. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.message: River levels have risen at the Liverpool Road river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday, 05/12/21. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Norton Green and Darlaston including Stoke on Trent, Lyme Brook between Newcastle under Lyme and Hanford, Fowlea Brook at Stoke on Trent and Ford Green Brook. Further rainfall is forecast today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 05/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Lower Coquet as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. There is less rainfall forecast today, 05/12/2021 however levels will remain high for most of the day before reducing. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and do not currently expect to issue any Flood Warnings. We are not expecting to close Warkworth flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
